body.p: What is the most likely shape of the distribution of age of death from trauma (accident, murder, suicide, drug overdose, etc.) when represented by a histogram?
Recall that we talked earlier about the shape of the distribution of age of death from natural causes (heart disease, cancer, etc.). Use a similar type of reasoning for the age of death from trauma.

response.feedback: Incorrect. If the distribution is symmetric—uniform, this would mean that deaths from trauma are equally likely to happen at any age. In fact, deaths from accidents, suicide, or drug overdose are more likely to happen to young people.

Incorrect. If the distribution is skewed left, this would mean that the bulk of deaths from trauma happen to the elderly. In fact, deaths from accidents, suicide, or drug overdose are more likely to happen to young people.

Correct. The bulk of deaths from trauma (accidents, suicide, drug overdose, etc.) happen at a younger age, and fewer at an older age. Therefore, we expect the distribution of age of death from trauma to be skewed right.

Incorrect. If the distribution is symmetric—unimodal, this would mean that the bulk of deaths from trauma happen to middle-aged people. In fact, deaths from accidents, suicide, or drug overdose are more likely to happen to young people.

Incorrect. If the distribution is symmetric—bimodal, this would mean that the bulk of deaths from trauma happen at two different times of life. In fact, deaths from accidents, suicide, or drug overdose are more likely to happen to young people.

part.hint: Review the shape and characteristics of each distribution.
